contextId.information: God uses this question to bring Ezekiel's attention to what the people were doing. AT: "I want you to understand why I hate what the people here are doing." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: do you see what they are doing?

contextId.information: God is commanding Ezekiel to look at what the elders are doing. AT: "look at what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: do you see what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark?

contextId.information: Yahweh is commanding Ezekiel to think about what he has just seen. AT: "Think about this ... man." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you see this ... man?

contextId.information: God uses this question to show that he is right to be angry at the people of Judah. AT: "I am right to be angry at the house of Judah because of these abominations that they are doing here." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it a little thing for the house of Judah to do these abominations that they are doing here?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel something he already knows. The question is a mild rebuke for the people who use the proverb. AT: "the people in the land of Israel have this proverb that says, 'The days are prolonged, and every vision fails.' (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: what is this proverb that you have in the land of Israel that says, 'The days are prolonged, and every vision fails'?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to rebuke the women who do these things. The implicit answer is, "no." AT: "Do not think that you will be able to save your own lives after you have hunted down my people!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will you hunt down my people but save your own lives?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the elders should not be inquiring of him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Should I permit them to inquire of me at all?" or "They should not be inquiring of me at all." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Should I be inquired of at all by them?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "a vine is not better than any tree with branches that is among the trees in a forest." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: how is a vine better than any tree with branches that is among the trees in a forest?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "they do not make a peg from it to hang things on it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: do they make a peg from it to hang anything on it?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to emphasize the negative answer. AT: "It will not prosper." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will it prosper?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to emphasize the negative answer. AT: "It will not grow." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: will it grow?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that this will certainly happen. AT: "It will wither when the eastern wind touches it." (See [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).
contextId.quote: Will it not wither when the eastern wind touches it?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this as a leading question in order to provide the answer. AT: "This is what these things mean." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do you not know what these things mean?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. AT: "He will certainly not succeed." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will he succeed?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. AT: "If he breaks the covenant, he will certainly not escape." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: If he breaks the covenant, will he escape?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the affirmative answer. AT: "it was my oath that the king of Jerusalem despised and my covenant that he broke." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).
contextId.quote: was it not my oath that he despised and my covenant that he broke?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel something he already knows. The question is a rebuke for the people who use the proverb. AT: "the people in the land of Israel have this proverb ... 'Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are made blunt.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: What do you mean, you who use this proverb ... 'Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are made blunt?'

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this as a leading question in order to emphasize the negative answer. AT: "He will certainly not live!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should he live? He will not live!

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question in order to emphasize the opposite. AT: "I do not greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked ... but I do greatly rejoice if he turns away from his way so that he may live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Do I greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked ... and not in his turning away from his way so that he may live?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the negative answer. AT: "then he will surely not live." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: then will he live?

contextId.information: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the positive answer. AT: "It is your ways that are unfair." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is it not your ways that are unfair?

contextId.information: The people use this question to insult Ezekiel and dismiss what he is telling them. AT: "He is merely telling parables" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Is he not a mere teller of parables?

contextId.information: This rhetorical question is used to make the audience think about what could happen. This question can be written as a statement. AT: "and it will be very frightening if the sword destroys the scepter" or "but it will be very frightening if the king cannot resist it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: but what if the scepter does not last?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize how hurt they will be when he punishes them. This question may be written as a statement. AT: "Your heart will not stand and your hands will not be strong on the days when I myself will deal with you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will your heart stand, will your hands be strong on the days when I myself will deal with you?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question as a command for Ezekiel. This question can be written as a statement. The cities of Jerusalem and Samaria are represented by Oholah and Oholibah. AT: "Son of man, you will judge Oholah and Oholibah!" or "Son of man, judge the people of those two cities represented by Oholah and Oholibah." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Son of man, will you judge Oholah and Oholibah?

contextId.information: This question expects a positive answer and emphasizes the results of Tyre's destruction. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "The islands will quake ... in your midst." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Will not the islands quake ... in your midst?

contextId.information: This question expects a negative answer to emphasize the irony when one who claims to be a god is destroyed by men. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "You will not say "I am a god" to the face of one who kills you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
contextId.quote: Will you truly say, "I am a god" to the face of one who kills you?

contextId.information: "Which of these trees in Eden had as much glory as you and was as great as you?" God asks Pharaoh this question to show him that the parable applies to him and his country. It can start with "So Pharaoh" or "So Egypt." (See" [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Which of the trees in Eden was your equal in glory and greatness?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to scold the leaders for not taking care of the people. AT: "Shepherds should feed the flock and take care of it." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Should not shepherds guard the flock?

contextId.information: This is the beginning of a question that God uses to scold Israel's leaders, who are spoken of as if they were the stronger animals in the flock that were unkind to the weaker ones. You can translate this as a statement as in the UDB. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Is it not enough ... feet

contextId.information: The people use a question to express their surprise at what they saw. AT: "I cannot believe these are really the people of Yahweh!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are these really the people of Yahweh?

contextId.information: These two questions are used to accuse Gog of attacking Israel without cause. These can be translated as statements. AT: "It is not right for you to assemble your army to plunder, to carry off silver and gold, to take their livestock and property, and to haul away much plunder!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Have you come to plunder? Have you assembled your armies ... to haul away much plunder?

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that Gog will indeed hear about the people living in Israel. AT: "On that day, when my people Israel are living securely, you will hear about them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: On that day ... learn about them

contextId.information: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he was the one who brought Gog to the land of Israel. AT: "You are the one ... bring you against them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: Are you not the one ... bring you against them?

contextId.information: This can be translated as a statement. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:ezk:08:14|8:15]]. AT: "Pay attentions to this" or "think about this carefully" (UDB). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
contextId.quote: do you see this
